page.title: 11Montacute House.
page.content: Montacute House was built in the years around 1600, at the end of Queen Elizabeth 1's reign, probably by William Arnold, a Somerset mason from near Wincanton. The work was done by local masons and the stone came from nearby Ham Hill. The Phelips Family who had once lived in Montacute House, could no longer afford to keep it in the 19th century so it was let to Lord Curzon. In 1931 the future of Montacute looked grim and the house might have been pulled down if Mr.Cook and the Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings had not bought it and presented it to the National Trust. It is now open to the public. {Open;April to Nov,12:30-6 p.m.Tea-room {& gift-shop.Large car-parks.
